narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained insights and knowledge about the global economy, discussing topics such as GDP, innovation, debt, crises, depressions, COVID-19, fiscal policy, globalization, and the political economy. We connected and compared trends to of different countries and grounded a lot of the information in the modern day times.

I learned to critically evaluate trends in the global economy and important macroeconomic research papers. This class covered a wide variety of concepts in macroeconomics, providing students a rigorous theoretical and empirical foundation in them.

We learned the economic forces that govern global economies like debt, crises, and financial institutions, and then applied these lessons to understand the theoretical underpinnings of recent historical and current events.
Broad overview of relevant topics in global macroeconomics. Focused a lot of the time on crises, first 2008-2009 then COVID specific information.
Insights into the global economy

I think this is the only course at Yale where I actually learned real world applications and analysis of economics and economic events. Additionally, I have a  better understanding of how to read and analyze economic literature.
thinking about the world at large through an economic lens

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of the course were the breadth of the material being discussed and the professor's ability to ground all of the material in the evidence from published economic papers. A weakness of the course is sometimes the depth of the material was not substantive as I would have hoped -- we often answered the question about what was happening and backed it up with economic evidence, but didn't always discuss why it was happening.

The strength of this course is Prof. Tsyvinsky. He brings a level of knowledge that is unmatched, a deep enthusiasm for economics, and a true enjoyment of teaching. He made seminar engaging and tailored our class to student interest. No weaknesses!

Prof. Tsyvinksi's broad knowledge is undoubtedly the strength of the course. The class hinges upon his facility with the broad, loosely connected range of topics we address. Sometimes, the class feels unfocused, but every lecture is interesting, and he is able to articulate complex topics clearly for students of all experience levels.

The course was well structured to allow student input. Prof. Tsyvinski listened to what students wanted to learn about, welcomed asking questions and encouraged students to write their papers on topics that they were passionate about. Readings were manageable and interesting.
Great course. Could be improved by clarifying arbitrary grading standards

Strengths: Prof Tsyvinski is absolutely amazing. A few times during the course, he mentioned that this course reaffirmed his faith in learning/education due to the small size and engagement, but I think it was actually the opposite -- Prof Tsyvinski reaffirmed all our faiths in learning. He is a professor who is truly passionate (and extremely knowledgeable) about his subject matter, and chiefly cares about imparting and discussing his (really interesting) insights with us. The course is designed to have two main papers that constitute our grade, but Prof Tsyvinski always stressed how these were only avenues for us to explore what interests and excites us. The class also had a casual, laid back atmosphere, and made me look forward to Thursday afternoons.

strengths: engaging, enjoyable discussion format, interesting topics, assignments tailored to interests
weaknesses: honestly none. This class was very well designed and executed.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The best practices were the professor's ability to communicate with the students in a small environment and answer any questions directly. It felt like a conversation some of the time, which was great to put in the larger presentations during the seminar format. The presentations that Professor Tsyvinski gave were incredibly substantive and organized and were always uploaded before the class meeting. A way that it could be improved was digging deeper into the way aspect to a lot of the data and evidence we analyzed.
Sometimes, long lectures with slides could get redundant. However, towards the end of the semester we had more discussion and student led presentations which were highly engaging.
the seminar was small enough to facilitate discussion with the whole class. no breakout rooms were necessary.
n/a
As a seminar, I think engagement was higher than in most lectures

I thought that Prof. Tsyvinski did a wonderful job at adapting the course to the virtual environment... obviously everyone would prefer to be in person, but he did a wonderful job of making the best of it -- even with time differences!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to another student; this is a great way to synthesize a lot of information that is discussed in introductory level economics coursed and place them into the context of real countries and their relationships to each other. This is a great course to discover and develop macroeconomic theory and to find different aspects of the macroeconomy that you are particularly interested in and may have a passion for pursuing more research later on.
Yes, for anyone interested in economics or simply interested in being better informed about key issues in current political discourse.

Absolutely. I think this course provides an immense amount of knowledge on global issues that any student would find useful. And Professor Tsyvinski is a wonderful and engaging professor who is obviously passionate about what he teaches and how his students are doing.
I would, if for nothing but to be able to pick Prof. Tsyvinski's brain.
Yes. Prof. Tsyvinski is really easygoing and welcomes whatever suggestions students have about topics they want to learn about.
yeah

YESSSS take it for Prof Tsyvinski!!! The readings are very interesting, the seminars are honestly just chill and fun and informative in the best way possible, but Prof Tsyvinski is the highlight - he selects pertinent readings, explains them and general economic concepts really well (which I would expect to know, but someone most classes at Yale focus on theoretical stuff as opposed to actual real world scenarios). He is also just an absolute joy to have in class, really kind and very passionate and knowledgeable about his subject matter
Yes! It's a fantastic economics course and i would recommend it to any student in the major.

Yes! Aleh is a great seminar leader, and the topics discussed are relevant and he does a great job introducing the important research in those areas. Would highly recommend to anyone interested in academically-informed discussion of economic issues.
Yes, very well taught and introduces you to a more applicable understanding of Economics in the real world
